my name is Cody Albert. I am on the

for short, and I've been doing that for
nine and a half years. So really excited
to hit those double digits next
presentation, I hope. Uh in that time I
have been supporting a number of teams
especially like the UI and editor teams
and as a result of that debugging is
kind of a huge part of what I do. Like
if I had to summarize my entire job in
three words I'd say I fix code. Uh
sometimes it's my code sometimes it's
engine code sometimes it's your code. Uh
sometimes we don't know whose code it is

up with a quote and this is from Brian
Kernigan in the elements of programming
style, legendary computer scientist,
inventor of the Hello World program. And
Brian says, "Everyone knows that
debugging is twice as hard as writing a
program in the first place. So if you're
as clever as you can be when you write
it, how will you ever debug it?" Um, a
similar sentiment was shared in 2013 on
Twitter by Felipe Fores. Debugging is
like being the detective in a crime
movie where you are also the murderer.
So, um I think it's it's clear that we
need good debug tools. Like there's
there's really nothing better. And so I

and check method. This is when you just,
you know, take a look at the code. You
think you see the issue, so you make a

coffee, come back and that didn't work.
But um this time for sure you see it.
So, you make another change, hit

you're frantically googling sunk cost

So, with that little bit of intro
pizzazz, uh, let's get into it. What is
Slate IM? Slate im is an immediate mode
wrapper for Slate. What is immediate
mode? You might be asking. Uh, we're
going to do a quick primer. So, doesn't
really have anything to do with Slate.
This is very generic cool information,
but most rendering APIs operate in one
of two modes. Either retained mode or
immediate mode. And they both have their
pros and cons. Uh, retain mode is where
we sort of store a state, a scene,
something in between frames. Um, we will
update that scene as things change. And
then when it's time to draw, we will
draw that state. So this is how like all
modern 3D renders tend to work. You know
like the forward and deferred render all
do this. We care about performance. Uh
the downside is that wherever there is
state there can be a bad state and then
you have to sort of debug that is like
what went wrong? What happened before?
We can't just address each frame as it
comes. Uh on the other hand you have
immediate mode APIs. This is where we
just redraw everything every frame. You
know we have some sort of a loop. We say
what do we need to draw this frame? We
put it all on screen. Uh it's super
flexible. It's data driven. If we don't
want to draw anything anymore, we just
stop and it goes away. Uh, but it's not
super efficient. You know, we we're
doing a lot of work. We probably don't
need to. So, um, quick pop quiz,
rhetorical question, I guess. What is
Slate?
The answer is kind of both. Um, it is
technically an immediate mode API out of
the box. Um, and that's because it's
used to build the editor, and the editor
is a really complex tool. We don't need
to run the editor at 60 frames per
second on a potato. That's fine. But
Slate is also the backbone of UMG. It's
used in game UI all the time. And then
we do care about performance. So we have
things like retainer panels, validation
panels or just global invalidation mode
which kicks the entire thing over to
being a retain mode API. So a little bit
of both. But this is Slate. So this is
an immediate mode only.
Hopefully a little bit easier to write.

Easy as that. Great. So, let's get into
what is in Slate. Like what comes out of
the box. Uh, and at the at the root of
it all, we've got widget roots. So there
are three types of roots. Every widget
you create in Slate IM needs to have a
root. This is the basis of creating all
your other things. Uh the first type is
the window route. So this is going to
create a standalone window. This is
great if you want to like move your tool
to another monitor, maybe display some
debug information. Um and that will give
you you'll give it a titles or a window
title and an initial size as we saw
before. Uh the second type is a viewport
route. So this is if you want the
content in the viewport which is more
like how you usually see Dr. gooey used
embedded directly in there. This could
be more useful if you want to be able to
show some debug stuff on a on a device
like on a console because you won't have
windows obviously. Uh you're going to
give it a viewport that you want to add
it to. And there's some layout settings
you can provide to decide where in the
viewport it's going to appear. And
third, we have exposed route. This is
sort of the more advanced use case, but
in in exposed roots, we don't actually
draw anything. We just give you an S
widget that wraps the whole thing and
you can embed that however you want. So
if you had an existing Slate tool that
you've been working on, maybe you are a
tools developer, but you kind of want to
